title: How long can you borrow an eBook from the library? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the Albuquerque Public Library system, it’s similar to the time you can keep a physical book and for the same reasons. The library has purchased N “copies” of the e-book and can only have N copies checked out at a time. I put copies in quotes because it doesn’t really mean the same thing as with a physical object, but in this case, it functions the same. I haven’t looked to see if they do here, but libraries could, in theory, offer unlimited copies of e-books that are in the public domain. The rules on these works aren’t a clear-cut as I’d like. Project Gutenberg offers unlimited copies of this kind of work. As I recall, they place some (probably unenforceable) restrictions on what you can do with the text. It probably wouldn’t be worth it for library system to get involved because things like Gutenberg already exist and why should they duplicate effort for no addition benefit? I suppose they could connect user up with these sorts of projects as a public service, which is after all, the business they are in.

It depends on what the publishers allow your library to set for checkout length. Call them and ask! For our library, most titles check out for at least 2 weeks. Some check out for 21 days, and a few of the just-released titles will check out for only 7 days initially. After a certain amount of time they will roll over to the 2 week list.
